What is YAGSL?

YAGSL is a Generic Swerve Library that aims to simplify the process of creating a comprehensive and complete SwerveDrive with best practices from MANY SwerveDrive examples. YAGSL supports pretty much every swerve drive configuration possible and if there is an issue we will address it as soon as possible and credit discoveries.

YAGSL is designed so you can just copy over your code onto a robot then configure the JSON files and your program will just work. If you develop multiple robots this could be a major benefit because your competition robot and practice robot can have the same codebase without changing anything.

We are thrilled to announce the latest and greatest update to YAGSL ‚Äî version 2025.0.0! With this release, we‚Äôve added some groundbreaking features and improvements, making YAGSL an even more powerful tool for controlling swerve drives and integrating with robotics simulations. Below, we‚Äôll walk you through the most exciting new changes and enhancements!

A quick overview of YAGSL features are:

  • Uses motor controller PID exclusively.
  • Data for each swerve module.
  • Compatible with Advantage Scope swerve widget.
  • Compatible with FRC Web Components.
  • Support for TalonFX, SparkFlex, and SparkMax without changing any of the code base.
  • An actual library as opposed to template code.
  • Documentation , yes even javadocs .
  • Most absolute encoders (even discontinued ones!) are supported!
  • Does not require a CommandBased project and could be implemented in a TimedRobot.
  • Advanced tuning for motor controller output limits and supply amps.
  • Simulation support.
  • An easy configuration webpage!
  • PathPlanner implemented.
  • PhotonVision support.

2025 Highlights

  • MapleSim Integration: Revolutionizing the Simulation
  • 254‚Äôs SwerveSetpoint Generator
  • PathPlanner Feedforward Integration
  • New AdvantageScope NetworkTable Keys
  • Configuration JSON Gear Ratios
  • TalonSRX Encoders by @WispySparks
  • Odometry and Simulation Color Updates
  • MAXSwerve Absolute Encoder Offsets fix.
  • NavX inverted offset fix.

Telemetry

All of these amazing features come right out of the box! You do not need some super complicated setup to take advantage of everything shown here! We exist to try to raise the floor of swerve drives and drivebases overall for FRC.

Introduction to YAGSL 2025

The 2025 release of YAGSL comes packed with exciting updates, ranging from new integrations with simulation tools like MapleSim to improved functionality and support for new hardware components. This update takes swerve drive control to a new level, making it easier and more efficient for teams to implement advanced swerve drive features while simultaneously enhancing their simulation capabilities.

Here are the major changes introduced in this release:

MapleSim Integration: Revolutionizing the Simulation

One of the most significant additions in YAGSL 2025.0.0 is the integration with MapleSim ‚Äî a powerful physics simulator designed to model and simulate mechanical systems in great detail. With this integration, you can now accurately model your swerve drive‚Äôs dynamics and performance using MapleSim, providing a better simulation experience and more accurate results.

This addition helps teams fine-tune their swerve drives without the need for physical hardware testing, which is particularly useful for iterative design processes. Many thanks to @catr1xLiu for making this integration a reality!

254‚Äôs SwerveSetpoint Generator

We‚Äôve also included an implementation of 254‚Äôs SwerveSetpoint Generator, a tool that allows you to generate swerve drive setpoints based on your robot‚Äôs desired position and orientation. This setpoint generator is incredibly useful for automating trajectory-following and is a core tool for teams looking to optimize their robot‚Äôs autonomous capabilities. It simplifies the process of generating swerve drive commands and reduces the likelihood of errors when programming autonomous routines.

PathPlanner Feedforward Integration

Thanks to @catr1xLiu, we‚Äôve added support for PathPlanner‚Äôs Feedforward model, which uses DCMotor modeling to predict the feedforward values required for accurate swerve drive movement along a path. This makes it easier to implement smooth, consistent motion control and trajectory following, reducing the risk of overshoot and other errors.

This update helps teams implement PathPlanner with confidence, knowing that they are getting the most out of their swerve drive system.

Odometry and Simulation Color Updates

We‚Äôve added a fun and functional visual update to the simulation! In the default simulation, the odometry reading is now shown in pink and yellow, while the simulation reading is displayed in red and green. This update makes it easier to distinguish between real-time odometry and the simulated data, improving clarity during testing and debugging.

image736√ó360 56.6 KB

Other features

  • AdvantageScope keys are now available under swerve/advantageScope
  • TalonSRX Encoders by @Wispy
  • Upgraded to the new REVLib configuration classes.
  • Redux Robotics CanAndGyro Support
  • Starting pose definition capabilities are now in the Example!
  • A configuration application like Tuner X Swerve Generator is coming soon!
  • Easy installation without required dependency troubles.

Breaking Changes

Gear ratios and wheel diameters must now be defined and the old method of conversion factors is no longer valid. Please refer to Standard Conversion Factors for the updated conversion factor formats.

Example from physicalproperties.json:

"conversionFactor": {
    "angle": 21.84,
    "drive": 0.872
  },

to

"conversionFactors": {
    "angle": {
      "gearRatio": 12.8,
      "factor": 0
    },
    "drive": {
      "gearRatio": 8.14,
      "diameter": 4,
      "factor": 0
    }
  },

This change allows us to support maple-sim to its fullest capabilities as well as calculate the DriveFeedforwards for SparkMax controlled motors (note: You should define the motor model if you are going to use the Feedfowards from PathPlanner if its atypical for the motor controller!)

Contributors and Thanks

We‚Äôd like to give a huge shout-out to the following contributors who made this release possible:

  • @Etaash-mathamsetty for their work on supporting kA and the feedforward system.
  • @WispySparks for adding support for TalonSRX encoders.
  • @catr1xLiu for integrating MapleSim, PathPlanner Feedforward, and DCMotor modeling.

And, of course, thanks to all of our dedicated contributors and users who continue to make YAGSL better with every release!

Links and Resources

To help you get the most out of YAGSL 2025.0.0, here are some valuable resources:

  • YAGSL Documentation
  • YAGSL Example Repository
  • YAGSL Library Docs

Vendordep:

https://broncbotz3481.github.io/YAGSL-Lib/yagsl/yagsl.json

We hope you‚Äôre as excited about this release as we are! Happy swerve driving, and happy coding!

Support YAGSL

If you‚Äôve found YAGSL helpful and want to support the project, consider buying us a coffee! Your donations help us continue to improve and maintain the library, ensuring it stays up-to-date and as useful as possible for the community.

Visit our Ko-Fi page to make a contribution. Every little bit helps, and we truly appreciate your support!

Want to support while also getting some cool merch? Visit https://shop.yagsl.com/ and pick up a desk mat, hoodie, swimsuit, and more!

Thank you for being part of the YAGSL community!

One thing I noticed when doing the build is that YAGSL pulls in an awful lot of libraries: 2 version of Phoenix, REV, Studica, maple, redux, etc. I understand the need, because YAGSL supports all the different motors and sensors. However, we still are working with a Rio v1.
